org.logicmill.util.hash

Class SpookyHashStream

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.logicmill.util.hash.SpookyHashStream

  • public class SpookyHashStream
extends java.lang.Object
    A non-cryptographic, 128-bit hash function with a stream interface.

    SpookyHashStream is a Java implementation of Bob Jenkins' SpookyHash V2 algorithm (see http://burtleburtle.net/bob/hash/spooky.html). SpookyHashStream accepts input data in a series of put operations. allowing data to be digested in heterogeneous fragments. The computation occurs as data is digested, so hash codes may be computed for streams of arbitrarily length. Simple usage includes three steps:

    1. initialize resets the internal state of the engine
    2. one or more put operations incorporate data into state of the engine
    3. hash computes a hash code for all of the data incorporated since the most recent initialize
    For example: 
     SpookyHashStream spooky = new SpookyHashStream();
 spooky.put(new short[] { 1, 2, 3, 5, 8 });
 spooky.put("hello").putFloat(3.14f).putBoolean(true);
 long[] result = spooky.hash();
 // hash code in result[0] and result[1]
     put methods return this (the hash engine}, allowing put operations to be chained: 
     spooky.put("hello").put(3.14f).put(true);
    Note that hash does not modify the state of the hash engine; it computes the hash code for all of the data added with put operations since the most recent initialize, regardless of whether hash has been invoked in the interim.

    The following code fragment illustrates the use of this class to compute a hash value for the contents of a file. 

     SpookyHashStream spooky = new SpookyHashStream();
 java.io.FileInputStream in = new java.io.FileInputStream(...);
 byte[] buffer = new byte[BUFSIZE];
 spooky.initialize();
 int numBytes = in.read(buffer);
 while (numBytes != -1) {
        spooky.put(buffer, 0, numBytes);
        numBytes = in.read(buffer);
 }
 long[] result = spooky.hash();
    This class is not thread-safe; an instance should not be used concurrently by multiple threaads. Like SpookyHash, the internal state of SpookyHashStream is initialized with a 128-bit seed value, in the form of two long values. A seed value is associated with the engine at construction time. This seed is used by default when initialize() is called. Alternatively, initialize(long, long) uses its parameters as a seed.

    All credit for design and hashing acumen goes to Bob Jenkins. Errors and poor implementation judgment are the responsibility of the author.

    Author:
    David Curtis
    See Also:
    http://burtleburtle.net/bob/hash/spooky.html, SpookyHash

        Constructs a new hash engine, with the specified default seed value.
        Parameters:
        seed0 - first half of the default seed value
        seed1 - second half of the default seed value

    • Method Detail

      • initialize

        public void initialize(long seed0,
              long seed1)
        Initializes the state of the hash engine with the specified seed value. Any buffered data retained from previous put operations will be discarded.
        Parameters:
        seed0 - first half of the seed value
        seed1 - second half of the seed value

      • initialize

        public void initialize()
        Initializes the state of the hash engine with the default seed value associated with this instance. Any undigested payload retained from previous update operations will be discarded.

        Returns:
        this (the engine)

      • hash

        public long[] hash()
        Computes the hash code for all data incorporated since the most recent initialize operation. hash does not modify the state of the engine.
        Returns:
        contains the computed hash code in the first two elements
